Hello Tim, thanks for another great episode, and now, if you will allow, for something completely different.
I've been discussing with some people on the LabPadre Discord, the questions posed below and hope that you will find the time to weigh in in your typical pithy style;

What do you think about the giant window array shown in SpaceX renders near the nose of Starship? To me this is clearly far more complex, heavy, vulnerable to failure, subject to undesirable thermal and optical excursions and far more costly than a mostly continuous steel hull.

I understand the psycological and aesthetic reasons for real windows, but the engineering and economic tradeoffs would seem to argue for using some form of internal display (projetors, screens, head mounted displays, etc) in place of spaceworthy windows, to give passengers the impression of seeing outside without poking a giant hole in the hull to accomodate the large panoramic forward window panels.

In Mars transit, I believe there are technical means other than windows that could be devised to provide a sufficiently immersive experience to at least equal that of widows, while also using fewer, more modestly sized transparent windows for direct passive observation where necessary or desirable to minimize costs and risks while serving the needs of the passengers for a sense of connection to space. It is also true that such means could provide an immersive sense of connection to orher places as, such as locales on Earth or Mars or any place else with appropriately formatted video files. This would provide psycological benefits passive windows cannot.

In LEO and Lunar excursion modes perhaps there are compelling economic and aesthetic arguments enough to outweigh the risks and costs of traditional spaceworthy windows.

Anyway, I would appreciate hearing your thoughts on this. Will the giant window ever fly?

It's about escape velocity, (wikipedia quote) escape velocity is the minimum speed needed for a free, non-propelled object to escape from the gravitational influence of a massive body.
The escape velocity from Earth is about 11,186 km/s (6.951 mi/s; 40,270 km/h; 36,700 ft/s; 25,020 mph; 21,744 kn)[1] at the surface. At the moon it's 2,38 km/s. The best long distance rifles and tanks can shoot bullets at about 1,75 km/s. So you need one of these up there choose a very light bullet and then you might be able to shoot something away from the moon. A space elevator seems a little impossible at the moment. I guess the best forever solution is creating mini fusion reactors, now possible due to new magnetic technology and improved fluxes. This you need to put on a rocket and shoot big volumes of high speed hydrogen ions for propulsion. And that's going to be the space elevator of the future. Two leaps forward is what we need to make an effective space elevator.

Luna-Earth space elevator can be done with a very thin tether, on the order of a couple of square inches maximum cross section IIRC. Once a month the Earth end would dip down into the upper atmosphere where it could be latched onto at subsonic speeds.

It is interesting to compare the control room of this mission versus the control room  for a SpaceX launch.  Two points popped out for me:  (1)  The median age for the N/G control room seems significantly higher and (2) there were no women on camera in the N/G control room.   I do not recall how many women were in the last SpaceX mission's control room.

??? Watching some of these live events makes one think. Watched the starliner abort today and thought about the dragon abort blow up... and was wondering: with the change of the Dragon abort to rupture plates, how does that set back starship? That is, my guess is that the valves used for the abort were chosen with the idea of using them for landing down the road... no longer an option with rupture plates instead of valves. The Starship effectively faces the same challenges with leaky valves and restarting engines... or did they just put the rupture plates in the Dragon to "get it out the door"?

@Everyday Astronaut - Tim, the moon rotates at <17 Kph, while its escape velocity is ~2.38 Kps. You’re right - Someone using a lunar space elevator would probably just fall back towards the moon & end up lithobraking. A lunar space elevator would only be practical if it went BEYOND the Lagrange Points.

Space elevator to Lagrange points 1, 2, 4, 5 is easily doable with steel-age tech, let alone modern tech.
An elevator to L-1 is a bridge between Luna and Earth.
An elevator to L-2 is a sling-shot to the rest.of the solar system.
Elevators to L-4 and L-5 would be an extension of lunar bases into space stations at those points.
Each elevator can connect to three places on the lunar equator and both poles.
Edit: And it should be possible to travel through an elevator network from any Lagrange point to any other Lagrange point or lunar elevator base.

I got you a legit question...  I was listening/watching this launch an heard one controller say "switching or engaging Velocity Steering" now i would assume velocity steering would be using a aerodynamic drag element on the vehicle to steer it.. Which got me thinking.. you always hear about gimbaled engines an the like to steer in that regard but ive never heard of a aerodynamic control feature to steer the rocket on the way up. I guess they want to limit as much aerodynamic friction as possible... but the size of a control surface would not need to be very big at all.  So the question...  Do rockets employ tech like im speaking of? also.. i did a quick time over distance calculation ... This particular rocket averaged 605 mph from launch to 100k feet... key word is averaged... im sure it was going much faster then 600mph at 100,000 feet mark.

I remember the 60's/70's quite well.  I was. just starting HS in 67! My dad worked at a company that made the plastic control knobs for Gemini XII, and the first three flights of Apollo.  I still have signed images of Ed White (G-IV), Ed "Buzz" Aldren (G-XII), and Neal Armstrong (A-II)!  That was a extremely exciting time for the nation and for all us dreamers who wanted to follow in their footsteps! Thanks for bringing back the excitement! ! As for me, I finally made a spaceflight, not as an astronaut but as a writer, in Sci-Fi! :). Love your passion for all of this! Try not to miss any of your videos. Keep it up you're awesome!

ELON said that the heaviest component in his rocket is the liquid oxygen.  This is very inefficient method for boosting a payload as the atmosphere is very dense at lower altitudes.  What he should do is fly using an atmosphere breathing engine to approximately 50,000ft.  Then engage a scramjet engine to boost to 100,000ft. At such time a self-contained rocket engine should be used to reach orbit and beyond.   SSTO examples are Skylon and VSS Unity.

How would you go about disproving the earth is flat using info only from this video?

I posit that if the earth is flat and the ISS does not exist then nothing would change in this video. The objective of this mission would be, of course, to pocket the money from the rocket launch and then dispose of the rocket. Only one thing would have to be changed and that is the altitude number to a stable one once "orbit" is reached (to hide loss of altitude due to falling). The booster would still end up in the ocean and, as you said, after a point in the mission the capsule is going fast enough that it will burn up on re-entry, destroying the evidence, without any further tampering.

Also, apart from a few managers, none of the employees of said company have to be complicit. In both cases the rocket is fully functional, constructed to the same specifications, and completes the same task. The only difference is that there is no rendezvous with the ISS and the payload just burns up prematurely during re-entry (since orbit is not possible).

I would be happy to hear your responses. You can also cite ancillary sources about this mission to further bolster your claims.

RD -170 is the most powerful,versatile, innovative design ever, and this engine alone kept Russia in space business after the fall of USSR.
What began as a compromise, to use 4 combustion chambers to avoid combustion instability,
but use common turbo pump assembly, became the best solution Russians ever make.
By developing one engine, they practically developed four.
If they need really big engine - 4 chamber configuration
We need medium size engine - 2 chamber configuration
We need small engine - 1 chamber configuration
Energomash never made a 3 chamber configuration, but if ,by any chance need such an engine, they could build it very easily.

44:30 "...why the ISS..." Science is just a small reason for the ISS. There is an upper limit to how much six people can do. The productivity per astronaut is extremely high, overall productivity is nowhere near what a modest university can do with hundreds on the ground.

What ISS really does is act as a peace process. If everything else on Earth went to hell diplomatically there will always be a groups of rocket scientists on either side having to constantly communicate to keep their respective heroes alive and back to Earth.
